title: Aaron Paul responds to criticism over lack of women in El Camino
text:
Aaron thinks there’ll be a ‘next time’ for women to get better roles (Picture: Netflix)

Aaron Paul has responded to fan backlash over the lack of women appearing in El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie.

The actor returned to his role as Jesse Pinkman one last time for the new role, which picks up at the end of the series which saw his bruised and beaten character ride off into an unknown future.

But as El Camino documented his final days in Albuquerque, New Mexico, viewers noticed there was next to no women around at all – with only a handful of female characters making it to screen (and spoiler: one of them was dead.)

Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, he responded: ‘I’m sorry that you have an issue with it. But maybe take it as a compliment that all the bad people happen to be men. Right?

‘Maybe they could’ve come up with a great villain, female character, but I don’t know. Another time!’

Picking up where the season finale left off, El Camino saw Jesse head to friends Skinny Pete (Charles Baker) and Badger (Matthew Lee Jones) for help, before making a deal with ‘The Disappearer’ Ed (Robert Forster) to help him get off the radar and start a new life.

His life as a captive of white supremacist meth dealer Todd Alquist (Jesse Plemons) was also told through a series of flashbacks.

As a result, it meant there was little room for women in the story.

In total, there were five women in any scene at all – with only two of whom getting lines.

El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie is available now on Netflix.
